quiz.title: Grade 12 Advanced Mechanics
quiz.subtitle: Unit 5, Quiz 5: Magnetic Fields from Currents (Biot-Savart & Ampere's Law)
quiz.subject: Physics

questions.question: What is the shape of the magnetic field lines around a long, straight current-carrying wire?
options: Radial lines pointing away from the wire.
Parallel lines along the length of the wire.
Concentric circles centered on the wire.
questions.explanation: The magnetic field forms concentric circles around the wire, with direction given by the right-hand rule. The field strength decreases with distance: $B = \frac{\mu_0 I}{2\pi r}$.

questions.question: Which rule is used to find the direction of the magnetic field around a straight wire?
options: Right-Hand Rule (Thumb = Current, Fingers curl = Field).
questions.explanation: Right-hand rule: point thumb in direction of conventional current (+ to -), and fingers curl in the direction of the magnetic field circles around the wire.

questions.question: The magnetic field strength ($B$) at a distance $r$ from a long straight wire is:
questions.explanation: From the Biot-Savart law: $B = \frac{\mu_0 I}{2\pi r}$, so $B \propto 1/r$. This is unlike electric fields from point charges, which follow $1/r^2$.

questions.question: What happens to the magnetic field at the center of a circular loop if the number of turns in the loop is doubled?
questions.explanation: Field at center of a circular loop: $B = \frac{\mu_0 I}{2R}$ per turn. For $N$ turns: $B = \frac{N\mu_0 I}{2R}$. Doubling $N$ doubles $B$, as fields from each turn add constructively.

questions.question: A "Solenoid" is a long coil of wire. The magnetic field inside an ideal solenoid is:
options: Uniform and parallel to the axis.
questions.explanation: Inside a long, tightly wound solenoid, the magnetic field is uniform (constant in strength and direction) and parallel to the solenoid axis: $B = \mu_0 n I$, where $n$ is turns per meter.

questions.question: To increase the strength of an electromagnet (solenoid), one should:
options: Increase the current and number of turns.
questions.explanation: Strength increases with: (1) more current $I$, (2) more turns $N$ per length, and (3) inserting a ferromagnetic core which amplifies the field by a factor $\mu_r$ (relative permeability).

questions.question: The constant $\mu_0$ (permeability of free space) has a value of approximately:
questions.explanation: $\mu_0 = 4\pi \times 10^{-7} \text{ T}\cdot\text{m}/\text{A}$. Option A is $\epsilon_0$ (permittivity), C is Coulomb's constant, D is Planck's constant.

questions.question: According to Ampereâ€™s Law, the line integral of the magnetic field around a closed loop is proportional to:
questions.explanation: Ampere's Law: $\oint \vec{B} \cdot d\vec{\ell} = \mu_0 I_{enc}$. The circulation of $\vec{B}$ around any closed loop equals $\mu_0$ times the net current passing through the loop.

questions.question: If current flows into the page through a wire, the magnetic field lines (from your perspective) will be:
options: Pointing toward the top of the page.
questions.explanation: Right-hand rule: point thumb into page (current direction), fingers curl clockwise around the wire. Thus magnetic field circles clockwise as viewed from above.

questions.question: The magnetic field outside a very long, tightly wound solenoid is approximately:
questions.explanation: For an ideal solenoid (infinite length), the external magnetic field is approximately zero. The field lines are confined inside and form closed loops through the solenoid.

scoreMessages.90: Excellent! You have mastered magnetic fields from currents, including Biot-Savart applications, solenoid fields, and Ampere's Law.
scoreMessages.70: Very good! Solid understanding of field patterns and calculations. Review the field equations for wires, loops, and solenoids, and the application of Ampere's Law.
scoreMessages.50: Fair. Focus on: 1) Field patterns around different conductors, 2) Formulas for $B$ from wires, loops, and solenoids, 3) Ampere's Law statement and meaning, 4) Factors affecting electromagnet strength.
scoreMessages.0: Start with the fundamentals: Review the right-hand rule for field direction, the Biot-Savart law for calculating fields, and the properties of solenoids as ideal electromagnets.
